Post Description:
Today is the first day of COVID-19 circuit breaking measures. It is timely that we also rounded up the debate on the Resilience and Solidarity Budgets.

Glad that all Members of Parliament supported the measures. They raised useful ideas to improve the policies to support businesses, workers and households through this crisis.

While we deal with immediate challenges, we must keep an eye on the future too. The MPs raised a relevant question: we do need to use the reserves now, but are we being fiscally prudent enough? Will we still have enough reserves to do more later, if the situation calls for it?

When this is over, the past will not come back. Hence DPM @hengsweekeat set up two initiatives to think ahead ‚Äî a taskforce on Emerging Stronger to cover the economy, as well as a new emphasis on social resilience under the Singapore Together Movement.

Beyond the Budget measures, it will be our own determination and discipline that will see us through, and keep us safe for the future. ‚Äì LHL (An empty Orchard MRT station on the first day of a month-long ‚Äòcircuit breaker‚Äô. / MCI Photo by Fyrol)

#SGUnited
#SGTogether
Comments: Stay strong SG! Hope things get better for you all. Sending blessings from China.

Post Description:
Sat down with local media today to talk about the Resilience Budget that @hengsweekeat announced in Parliament yesterday, and what lies ahead as the COVID-19 pandemic turns the world upside down.

We are heading into the storm with a major $55 billion package to help save jobs and businesses, support households, and keep our economy going. If the situation worsens, we are ready to do more.

The impact on our economy has been huge. This is only the second time ever we are drawing on our reserves. The last time was for the Global Financial Crisis in 2009. We will be drawing up to $17 billion to fund the support measures, more than triple what was drawn in 2009.

I have no illusions that this will be all we need. Nobody can tell what lies ahead. COVID-19 has shown starkly how vulnerable we are, and how our existential threats essentially remain the same, despite Singapore going from third world to first. The COVID-19 pandemic will be the formative experience for this generation of Singaporeans. If we remain vigilant, resolute, and united, I am confident we will get through this together.

You can watch the full interview here on the PMO YouTube channel (click on the link in my profile) ‚Äì LHL

#SGUnited (MCI Photo by Zinkie Aw)
Comments: Pls waive income tax for a year ! Its added income for the middle income bracket that do not enjoy.much from the supplementary budget and yet have to contribute to income tax to support these measures . At least I can use my money to help myself and my family

Post Description:
Diplomacy in the time of COVID-19.

Held a virtual bilateral meeting with Australian PM @scottmorrisonmp via video conferencing today. While COVID-19 has certainly made travelling harder or even impossible altogether, technology can bridge the gap and enable us still to communicate with one another and get things done.

PM Morrison and I had a candid and fruitful discussion on the COVID-19 situation, our extensive economic cooperation, and sustainability. We also witnessed the signing of a treaty on military training and two MOUs on Artificial Intelligence and Data Innovation.

Singapore and Australia enjoy close and multifaceted ties, with warm people-to-people ties. Australia is a popular destination for Singaporeans ‚Äì not just for holidays and visiting friends, but also for studying. The SAF trains in Australia and our two armed forces have a long history of cooperation. I am confident that we will deepen our bilateral relationship further in the future. ‚Äì LHL (MCI Photos by Lee Jia Wen)
Comments: You‚Äôre amazing I love you üò≠‚ù§Ô∏è

Post Description:
Diplomacy in the time of COVID-19.

Held a virtual bilateral meeting with Australian PM @scottmorrisonmp via video conferencing today. While COVID-19 has certainly made travelling harder or even impossible altogether, technology can bridge the gap and enable us still to communicate with one another and get things done.

The SAF trains in Australia and our two armed forces have a long history of cooperation. I am confident that we will deepen our bilateral relationship further in the future. ‚Äì LHL (MCI Photos by Lee Jia Wen)
Comments: Dear PM Lee: In this COVID-19 situation, we have recognised the hard work and sacrifices of medical and cleaning professionals, and many other people at the frontline. Very seldom do I hear fellow Singaporeans express gratitude for what they have in their lives (roof over their head, access to education and healthcare, food on the table, clean water and air, no guns, no wars, no natural disasters, low crime rate).... let alone appreciate the government‚Äôs effort. I do know many who take things for granted, nit-pick, and do not contribute as much to solutions. So besides being thankful for the frontline staff, I want to thank you, the ministers, government officers and everyone behind the scenes, for working tirelessly for the nation. All of you worry, plan and exert yourselves so much, just so that Singapore stays safe and well. THANK YOU. I hope everyone will have enough rest, be safe, and be in good health. I hope Singaporeans will be calm, empathetic, compassionate and measured in how they relate to fellow humans during this difficult period and in the years to come.

Post Description:
Diplomacy in the time of COVID-19.

Held a virtual bilateral meeting with Australian PM @scottmorrisonmp via video conferencing today. While COVID-19 has certainly made travelling harder or even impossible altogether, technology can bridge the gap and enable us still to communicate with one another and get things done.

I am confident that we will deepen our bilateral relationship further in the future. ‚Äì LHL (MCI Photos by Lee Jia Wen)
Comments: I am not sure about others, but personally I am extremely disappointed with this Unity Budget. I would like to quote a Yahoo commentator who wrote this feedback (Quote) : "Veteran@VOTE2 hours ago singapore reserves are money mainly from past bearers and should be given to ALL singaporean household across the board, whom also facing the virus crisis. not just those whom got lay off due to the crisis, whom are mostly aliens. -- it will be exploited by unscrupulous employers to report 'lay offs' then 're-hired' the same after 3 months. (Unquote) There are other loopholes. E.g. Landlords who gained on zero property tax if they do not pass down the benefits to their tenants what can tenants do ? Lose Lose ? If landlords strategy is to use the gained benefits to wait out for the crisis to be over, they can easily get new tenants. Even if the landlords pass the savings, is there a clear guideline ? What can tenants do if landlords "give them bread crumbs " ? I listened to the Unity Budget. It seems complex, not easy to understand for many laymen or commoners. For those unemployed  due to other valid reasons say since last year, what assistance for these groups really ? Maybe I am not as smart as our leaders, but this Unity Budget for sure is confusingly complex. If Govt is afraid of giving too much direct cash handouts (as some may misuse it such as gambling), why not have assistance as such : Govt to pay 50% of PUB bills for the next 12 months ? Note that people are encouraged to do more hand washing. Surely water bills will shoot up. Or, plus S&CC charges to be waived for the next 12 months ? Whatever costs burden reduced is a good help during this crisis. For those affected that are low on CPF ordinary account balance but still have HDB mortgages to service, a top-up of 6 months equivalent will help with "straight, direct beneficial effect'. People can see it. People can feel the benefts straightaway. And correct me if I am wrong, up the skilllscredit $ ? Now? You want people to go for "mass training or learning of skills conducted in groups" now ? At this social distancing times ? From : a PAP supporter. @hengsweekeat@khawboonwan@lawrencewongst @teocheehean

PM Morrison and I had a candid and fruitful discussion on the COVID-19 situation, our extensive economic cooperation, and sustainability. We also witnessed the signing of a treaty on military training and two MOUs on Artificial Intelligence and Data Innovation.

Singapore and Australia enjoy close and multifaceted ties, with warm people-to-people ties. Australia is a popular destination for Singaporeans ‚Äì not just for holidays and visiting friends, but also for studying. The SAF trains in Australia and our two armed forces have a long history of cooperation. I am confident that we will deepen our bilateral relationship further in the future. ‚Äì LHL (MCI Photos by Lee Jia Wen)
Comments: social distancing game going strong

Post Description:
This morning, I held a dialogue with grassroots leaders on COVID-19 and what lies ahead for Singapore. This was a follow up to my TV broadcast on Thursday.

Fighting COVID-19 is difficult enough. But we also need to deal with COVID-19‚Äôs enormous impact on our economy.

Yesterday, the Government released the report of the Electoral Boundaries Review Committee's (EBRC), which the Committee had just completed.

The General Elections must take place before 21 April 2021. They can only be called after the electoral registers are updated. This will take about a month.

When to hold elections? That depends on the situation, and the outlook.

Singapore faces grave and extended challenges.

We can‚Äôt tell when the pandemic will end, but it will likely last at least this year, and quite possibly longer.

The economic hit will likely be more serious than the Global Financial Crisis, and longer-lasting too, even beyond the end of the pandemic.

I fully expect things to get more serious before they start getting better.

We have two choices. Either hope and pray that things will stabilise before the end of the term so that we can hold elections under more normal circumstances ‚Äì but we have no certainty of that.

Or else call elections early, knowing that we are going into a hurricane, to elect a new government with a fresh mandate and a full term ahead of it, which can work with Singaporeans on the critical tasks at hand.

If we have to hold elections before COVID-19 is over, we will take all the precautions necessary, so that parties can campaign effectively, and people can vote safely.

At stake are jobs, businesses and lives.

Which way to go, and the elections date, will depend on what will best see Singapore through this major crisis.

COVID-19 may well turn out to be the crisis that defines this generation of Singaporeans. We must gird ourselves to overcome this together, and show the world what Singapore can do. ‚Äì LHL

#SGUnited (MCI Photos by Fyrol)
Comments: Hi Mr LEE tks for ur friendship appreciate

Post Description:
This year‚Äôs Budget has extra significance. It provides critical support for Singaporeans and our economy as we deal with the COVID-19 outbreak.‚†Ä ‚†Ä

We are able to do this because of our fiscal prudence and discipline over many years. Together, we have put aside enough to cope with a rainy day like this.‚†Ä ‚†Ä

The Stabilisation and Support Package for workers and businesses will help tide them through the immediate term. The Care and Support Package will assure families and households. Meanwhile, we must continue to steward our resources and strengths, so that we are ready to grow again when the outbreak ends. ‚†Ä ‚†Ä

While we deal with this outbreak, let us continue to look out for one another, and keep building Singapore together. ‚†Ä
You can find out more at the MOF Budget website: www.singaporebudget.gov.sg‚†Ä
‚†Ä
‚Äì LHL‚†Ä
‚†Ä
#SGBudget2020‚†Ä
‚†Ä
(DPM & Finance Minister @hengsweekeat arriving at Parliament to present Budget 2020. / MCI Photo by Fyrol)
